column1: West Lafayette () is a city in Wabash Township
column5: about 65 miles (105 km) northwest of the state capital of Indianapolis and 103 miles (166 km) southeast of Chicago. West Lafayette is directly across the Wabash River from its sister city
column8: 596.  It is the most densely populated city in Indiana and is home to Purdue University.

column1: Augustus Wylie laid out a town in 1836 in the Wabash River floodplain south of the present Levee. Due to regular flooding of the site
column2: Wylie's town was never built. The present city was formed in 1888 by the merger of the adjacent suburban towns of Chauncey
column5: located on a bluff across the Wabash River from Lafayette
column6: Indiana. The three towns had been small suburban villages which were directly adjacent to one another. Kingston was laid out in 1855 by Jesse B. Lutz. Chauncey was platted in 1860 by the Chauncey family of Philadelphia
column7: wealthy land speculators. Chauncey and Kingston formed a municipal government in 1866 which selected the name "Chauncey".The new town of Chauncey remained a small suburban village until Purdue University opened in 1869. In 1871 Chauncey voted to be annexed by Lafayette because it was unable to provide the infrastructure (such as improved streets
column9: police and fire protection). Lafayette voted against annexing Chauncey because of the high cost of the many improvements that the village lacked. In May 1888
column10: the town of Chauncey voted to change its name to West Lafayette after a petition signed by 152 electors. By that time
column11: the growth of the university was fueling the growth of the little town. The address of Purdue University was given as "Lafayette
column12: Indiana" until well into the twentieth century. West Lafayette never gained a railroad depot and lagged several years behind Lafayette in the establishment of municipal infrastructure and services.  Today
column13: West Lafayette has established itself as a separate city
column14: with independent services and unique neighborhoods distinct from those of its sister city

column2: the City of West Lafayette approved an annexation that placed much of the Purdue University academic campus and residence hall system within the official boundaries of the municipality for the first time. This expansion also included a large section of the US Highway 231 corridor that was previously part of unincorporated Tippecanoe County.Alpha Tau Omega Fraternity House

column1: The city of West Lafayette has its fair share of non-profits
column2: many of whom are committed to preserving the arts. Organizations like the Tippecanoe Arts Federation (TAF) has a mission to "grow the arts". The International Center of West Lafayette helps them to achieve this goal by being a member organization of TAF.

column1: West Lafayette lies in central Tippecanoe County and overlooks the Wabash River
column2: which borders the city on the east and south. Most of the city lies in eastern Wabash Township
column3: though a small portion on the northeast side extends into Tippecanoe Township. Elevations range from slightly over 500 feet (150 m) near the river to more than 720 feet (220 m) in northern parts of the city near U.S. Route 52.

column2: West Lafayette has a total area of 7.63 square miles (19.76 km2)
column3: of which 7.62 square miles (19.74 km2) (or 99.87%) is land and 0.01 square miles (0.03 km2) (or 0.13%) is water.

column1: The city's elected officials consist of the mayor
The nine-member Common Council holds the city's legislative authority
column2: and makes the laws through ordinances
column4: resolutions and motions. The city is divided into 6 districts
column5: and the Common Council consists of one council member from each district
column6: plus three at-large council members. Elected by the council members
column7: the president of the Common Council presides over the council meetings and is first in the line of succession should the mayor not finish his or her term of office.

column1: All city elected officials have term of office of four years with no limit on the number of terms. Regular elections for all offices are held at the same time in the odd year preceding the presidential election year.The following is a list of all mayors of West Lafayette since the position began in 1924.
West Lafayette is the home of Purdue University's main campus

The West Lafayette Community School Corporation administers three schools. The school district is not coterminous with the municipality; areas annexed by the city after 2000 continue to be served by county schools. Students attend West Lafayette Elementary School (formerly Cumberland Elementary School) through third grade
column2: while students in grades 4–6 attend West Lafayette Intermediate School. Students in the 7th grade and above attend West Lafayette Junior-Senior High School.The Seventh-day Adventist Church operates Pleasantview SDA School which offers courses for grades K–8
column3: and the Montessori School of Greater Lafayette teaches K–6.  There are other schools
column5: that have a West Lafayette address
column6: but these are actually located outside the city limits.

column1: Approximately 77% of West Lafayette's population age 25 or older hold a bachelor's degree or higher according to the U.S. Census 2005–2007 American Community Survey. The city ranks sixth highest on this measure among U.S. municipalities between 20

column5: and an Ivy Tech Community College branch.
